lev1.title: GENERAL
lev1.para: Spicer's Stamped Angle-Spring Clutch ( Figure 1 and Figure 2) is a 14" pull-type clutch specifically engineered for Class 6 and 7 medium-duty trucks with flat-flywheel diesel engines. It offers plate load capacities of up to 3000 lbs. for engines delivering up to 900 ft-lbs. of torque.

The Stamped Angle-Spring Clutch is available with dampened discs only. Options include: 1 1/2", 1 3/4" and 2" ten-spline applications; single or two-plate disc assemblies; Kwik-Adjust or self-adjusting components; greaseable bearings; built-in free travel.

lev1.title: OPERATION
lev1.para: The purpose of a clutch is to transfer the power of the engine from the flywheel to the transmission. At the point in which clutch engagement is initiated, the transmission input shaft may either be stationary, as when the vehicle is at a standstill, or rotating at a different speed than the flywheel, as in the case of upshifting or downshifting. Once the clutch is fully engaged, however, both the flywheel and the transmission input shaft will rotate at the same speed.

To perform this function, a clutch is equipped with a disc which has friction surfaces known as facings. As the clutch pedal in the cab is depressed, the pressure plate is drawn away from the flywheel, freeing the disc(s) from contact with the flywheel friction surface. At this point the clutch is disengaged and the transfer of power from the engine to the transmission is interrupted.

As the clutch pedal is released, the disc(s) is clamped between the flywheel and the pressure plate. The discs are designed to slip for a short period of time as they gradually accept the torque of the flywheel. As pressure increases, the discs accept the full torque of the engine, and rotate at the same speed as the flywheel. At this point engagement is complete and the power of the engine is transferred to the transmission.

lev2.title: OPERATING PRINCIPLES
lev2.para: The Angle-Spring Clutch operates under indirect pressure. That means the pressure springs are located away from the pressure plate, rather than directly on it, and the spring load is applied through a series of six levers. Spicer's Angle-Spring differs from most other conventional clutches in that the plate load and release bearing load are not directly proportional to the spring load.

lev3.title: Engaged Position
lev3.para: Pressure plate load is the result of the axial load of the springs multiplied by the lever ratio. The pressure springs are positioned at an angle to the centerline of the clutch with their ends attached to the flywheel ring (cover) and the release sleeve retainer. As the release sleeve retainer, including the release sleeve and the release bearing, is moved toward the flywheel, the springs pivot freely without bending or buckling.

lev3.title: Released Position
lev3.para: When the clutch pedal is released, spring load increases but axial load decreases resulting in reduced pedal effort. The plate load is obtained from the axial component of the spring force multiplied by the lever ratio. The axial component of the spring force changes with release bearing movement, but not in direct proportion to the spring load.

lev3.title: Worn Engaged Position - Before Adjustment
lev3.para: When facings wear, spring load reduces but axial load remains constant. As the clutch wears, the release sleeve assembly moves toward the flywheel, and the pressure springs elongate and lose load. The axial component of the reducing spring force, however, remains essentially constant. Therefore, the plate load remains constant throughout the life of the clutch. In the worn position, the assist springs apply more load, indicating that it's time for a clutch adjustment.

lev3.title: Worn Engaged Position - After Adjustment
lev3.para: When the clutch is adjusted to compensate for the facing wear, the pressure plate position does not move, but the rotated adjusting ring moves the levers toward the transmission, thus pushing the release sleeve and bearing assembly that direction also. This in turn re-establishes the internal spring position back to an as-new setting for continued clutch use.

note.para: Spicer clutches should be replaced when adjustment cannot correct for a loss of free pedal or a slipping clutch.
